March 5, 1967
Mr* Albert P* Fredette
Station Manager^WAMC-FM
Albany Medical College
47 New Scotland Avenue
Albany9 New York
Dear Ali
It was good to see you again and be able to spend
so much time talking with you at the MAES Region II
meeting last week.
As I discussed with you, I am hopeful that we can
really do some good in a very tangible way for
educational radio on the East Coast during the
coming months. This belief is strengthened,
obviously, by President Johnson’s Educational
Message and the introduction of the Public Tele-
vision Act of 1 Ml by Senator Magnuson in the
Senate last"witifiST For the first time, educational
radio is a part of the package!
As you know, HER is in the final stages of completing
a major research project on the needs and status of
educational radio in the United States. This pro¬
ject will result in a Report, perhaps as compre¬
hensive in its own way as the Carnegie Report was
for ETV. It will serve as the basis for documenting
educational radio’s case before Congress. While
the definite hearing dates have not been set yet,
the latest grapevine suggests that it could happen
in a number of weeks.
In short, I need help—I need your help—and I need
it as soon as possible. In a moment of weakness, you
offered to help me in this crucial undertaking in
any appropriate way. Since I believe you implicitly,
I respectfully request the pleasure of your company
at the nA£B headquarters in Washington for as many
hours and days you can find (hopefully in the next
week or two) to aid in the analysis of material as
it relates particularly to the Eastern states.
